notesStmt.note: Edited by Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.

Dates given according to Lady-Day dating.

Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 28. THE Parliamentary Intelligencer, COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence, with the Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order. From Monday July 2. to Monday July 9. 1660.
Coppenhagen June 17.
div.p:
THe Twenty ≈øecond in≈øtant, the Swedes removed their Camp from before this place, and ≈ølighted all their Fortifications. They have ≈øcattered in all the ≈ømall places round about us all the forces they had here, amounting to about 3500 Hor≈øe and Foot, and whil≈øt they are bu≈øie about the execution of the other Articles of the Treaty, the King of Denmark
‚Ä¢ s preparing a great Fleet, to tran≈øport out of this I≈øland all the Swedi≈øh Militiaes, who are reported to amount yet to above 10000 men. The two Amba≈ø≈øadors of the States General of the United Provinces, and the Engli≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadors are gone to Stockholm, to congratulate the
Queen Regent of Swedland, upon the conclu≈øion of that Peace; and Mr. Hannibal See≈øted is likewi≈øe to repair thither with two Coun≈øellors of State, of his Dani≈øh Maje≈øty, to propound to her Maje≈øty and to the States of that Kingdom an Equivalent in≈øtead of the I≈øle of Bornholme, which by vertue of the ≈øame Treaty, is to be re≈øtored within a years time to the Crown of Swedland, the other Amba≈ø≈øadors of Holland having order to remain here, untill the Ratification of the ≈øaid Treaty doth come.

This week the Amba≈ø≈øador that was ≈øent by the Emperor to be pre≈øent at the Treaty of Oliva, went away for Vienna, as did the Count of Koning≈ømark, upon the advice he had that the Duke of Curland was ree≈øtabli≈øhed in his Dominions. It is thought that the ≈øaid Count is gone to War≈øow to conclude a ≈øtrict alliance between Swedland and Poland, for a conjunction of the Forces of both the Crowns again≈øt the Mu≈øcovites, who are marching with a mo≈øt potent Army, which is to be commanded by the Grand Duke him≈øelf, which hath obliged his Poli≈øh Maje≈øty to ha≈øten the Dyet, wherein a ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to the Crown is to be nominated, and the mo≈øt ≈øpeedy means how to rai≈øe an Army of four≈øcore thou≈øand men, to be likewi≈øe debated. Our Magi≈øtrates have ≈øent ≈øome Deputies to War≈øow, to demand the revocation of ≈øome new Impo≈øitions laid on all kinde of Merchandizes and Wares; but although our commerce be exceedingly prejudiced by it, there is ≈øo much the le≈øs likelihood of obtaining that demand, in regard the moneys accruing by the ≈øaid Impo≈øitions, are particularly de≈øigned for that War, in ca≈øe the States, upon their next meeting, do not finde ≈øome other way to get money for it.

The Dani≈øh Forces commanded by the Count Eber≈øtein about Tonningen, having received Orders to march towards
Eyder≈øtede, eight Companies of them are gone into Gluck≈øtadt, to reinforce the Garri≈øon there, and the re≈øt are to remain in the County of E ‚Ä¢ nnembergh. The young Count
‚Ä¢ on ‚Ä¢ ng≈ømark, who was detained pri≈øoner in Gluck≈øtadt, is relea≈øed, with General Horn and the other Swedi≈øh pri≈øoners.

All things are making ready for the march of the Imperial Forces that are in Pomerania and Mecklenburgh, as al≈øo for the removing of the Swedi≈øh Forces out of Zealand, and the I≈øles of L ‚Ä¢ land, Fal≈øter and Moen. The Swedi≈øh Forces are to be tran≈øported into Swedland, and into the Archbi≈øhoprick of Bremen, and the Imperial Forces to pa≈øs into Bohemia, from whence the Emperor doth intend to draw his Forces to be ≈øent into Hungary. It is ≈øuppo≈øed that a Dyet is to be very ≈øuddenly called to make an alliance with the Princes of the Empire, again≈øt the Grand Signior. The King of Denmark is likewi≈øe to repair very ≈øpeedily to Flensburgh, to give them the nece≈ø≈øary Orders, and to reform his Militia; but it is not thought he will disband his German Forces, which he intends to make u≈øe of as occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerve.

This day the Mayor of S. Albans, accompanied with Mr. Foxwi≈øt the Recorder, and ≈øome of the principal Burge≈ø≈øes his brethren, as the Repre≈øentatives of the ≈øaid Corporation, made their humble Addre≈øs to his Maje≈øty, the Recorder making a ≈øhort and pithy ≈øpeech by way of congratulation of his Maje≈øties happy re≈øtoration to his Royal throne, and a≈ø≈øurance of their loyalty and allegiance to his Maje≈øty, and pre≈øented him with a re≈øignation of the Fee farm rent purcha≈øed by the Corporation in his Maje≈øties ab≈øence, and the arrears incurred in the mean time.

Which his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed graciou≈øly to accept, and to expre≈øs his acceptance thereof, and that the Corporation
≈øhould, as occa≈øion required, participate of his Royal grace and favor.

I have as I acquainted you in my la≈øt, made enquiry into the bu≈øine≈øs of Captain Rolle, which was contradicted in ≈øome late Pamphlets; but upon di≈øcour≈øe with Sir James Smith and Mr. Calma ‚Ä¢ y, I find that the ≈øaid Captain Rolle was ≈øei≈øed for ≈øpeaking words, and that Mr. Calmady giving too much credit to him that brought the Note, did in ha≈øte ≈øigne it.

Wedne≈øday, Doctor Colladon Deputy from the Commonwealth of Geneva, having pre≈øented unto his Maje≈øty the Letters of the Lords Seyndies and Magi≈øtrates, and of the Pa≈øtors and Profe≈ø≈øors of that place, congratulating his Maje≈øties happy return and re≈øtauration to his Kingdoms: And demanded in their name of his Maje≈øty, the continuation of his Royal favor and good affection towards them. His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to return them thanks for the expre≈ø≈øion of ≈øo cordial a re≈øpect, and to give the ≈øaid Deputy a very gracious and acceptable an≈øwer upon his demand.

His Maje≈øty having been plea≈øed to be≈øtow a Grant for the Degree and Honor of Baronet upon Nicholas Steward of Hartley Mawdit, in the County of Southampton E≈øq a Patent pa≈ø≈øed under the Great Seal of England, for conferring the ≈øaid Honor and Degree of Baronet upon the ≈øaid Sir Nicholas Steward accordingly.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p: On Monday la≈øt, Colonel Sir John Robin≈øon, Alderman of London, and a Member of this Parliament, was by his Maje≈øty made Lieutenant of the Tower of London; an action mo≈øt acceptable not only to the City and Parliament, but indeed to the whole Nation, the very Pri≈øoners them≈øelves being glad of his company.

The Kingdom having for a long time, by rea≈øon of his Maje≈øties ab≈øence, been troubled with the Evil, great numbers have lately flock'd for cure. His Sacred Maje≈øty on
Monday la≈øt touched Two hundred and fifty in the Banqu ‚Ä¢ ting-hou≈øe; among≈øt whom, when his Maje≈øty was delivering the Gold, one ≈øhuffled him≈øelf in out of an hope of profit, which had not been ≈øtrok'd; but his Maje≈øty pre≈øently di≈øcovered him, ≈øaying, This man hath not yet been touch'd. His Maje≈øty hath for the future appointed every Friday for the cure; at which time Two hundred, and no more, are to be pre≈øented to him; who are fir≈øt to repair to Mr. Knight his Maje≈øties Chyrurgion, living in the Cro≈øs-guns in Ru≈ø≈øel ≈øtreet, Covent garden, over again≈øt the Ro≈øe-Tavern, for their Tickets. That none might lo≈øe their labor, he thought fit to make it known, that he will be at his ho ‚Ä¢ e every Wedne≈øday and Thur≈øday from two till ≈øix of the clock, to attend that ≈øervice: And if any per≈øon of quality ≈øhall ≈øend to him, he will wait upon them at their lodgings, upon notice given to him.
On Tue≈øday, his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to be at ≈øupper with the Lord Berclay, where he was very highly entertained.

His Maje≈øty hath been graciou≈øly plea≈øed to make Sir William Compton Brother to the Earle of Northamton, Ma≈øter of his Maje≈øties Ordnance; Co ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l William Leg Lievtenant of the Ordnance, Per≈øons that have ≈øuffered with his Maje≈øty in all his Troubles: and Major Francis Nicols Surveyor of his Ordnance for his faithfulne≈øs in adhering to his Excellency in all the≈øe late changes.

The≈øe following were re≈øtored to their Offices being formerly put out for ≈øerving his Maje≈øty, viz. Edward Sherborne to his place of Clerke to his Maje≈øties Ordnance: Mr. Mar≈øh to his place of Storekeeper, and Mr. Clarke formerly Commi≈ø≈øary General in his late Maje≈øties Army, to his place of Clarke of the Deliveries.
His Maje≈øty conferred on Mr. Hore the Office of Comptroller of His Maje≈øties Mint.

That the Soldiery may ≈øee the affection that his Sacred Maje≈øty hath for the Arm;, he hath been plea≈øed to do them ≈øo much honor‚ñ™ as to take that Regiment that was lately
Col. Unton Crooks, for his own, which is now ≈øt ‚Ä¢ led The Royal Regiment; what the names of the Officers are, you may ≈øee in the next. His Highne≈øs the Duke of York hath ≈øo far honored the Regiment of the Lord Falconberg, as to own it, which is now called the Duke of Yorks Regiment, the Lord Falconberg and the Officers being ≈øtill continued.

div.head: From his Excellencies Quarters at the Cockpit.
div.p: His Excellency hath been plea≈øed lately to change ≈øome Officers, and di≈øpo≈øe their Commands to others. He hath given th ‚Ä¢ comm ‚Ä¢ nd of the ‚Ä¢ roop‚ñ™ late Captain Shermans in the Lord Vi≈øcount Falklands R ‚Ä¢ gim ‚Ä¢ nt, to Col. Henry Heylin.
The Troop that was late Captain Greenwoods in the ≈øame Regiment, to Capt. Tho. Morley.
The Company late Major Waterhou≈øes in Col. Daniels Regiment, to Capt. Leonard Aizay.

His Excellency hath likewi≈øe commi≈ø≈øioned Major Adam Brown, br ‚Ä¢ ther to Sir Ambro≈øe Brown, to be Major of Sir Anthony A≈øhley Coopers Regiment, being about to confer a greater honor on Major Harley.

div.head: We≈øtmin≈øter.
div.p: Phinehas Pain that was lately Committed upon mi≈øinformaon given, that he was the per≈øon that executed his late Maje≈øty, is, upon Examination, di≈øcharged.

div.head: Naples the 5 of June 1660.
div.p: Our Vice Roy having received an expre≈øs from the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador re≈øiding at Rome, ≈øent to give him notice of the conclu≈øion of the Peace of the Empire, he cau≈øed pre≈øently the Te Deum to be ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ g for it, in the Church of St. James, in the pre≈øence of all our Magi≈øtrates, and with the noy≈øe of all the Canons of our Ca≈øtles, and other tokens of joy ordinarily made u≈øe of on ≈øuch occa≈øions.

div.head: Madrid 9 June 1660.
div.p:
The Order of our Lady of the mercy and redemption of
the Slaves, having ≈øent ≈øome Deputys to Algier, about March la≈øt, namely ≈øome Fryers of the Province of Ca≈øtille and Andalou≈øia, they brought from thence, about the later end of the la≈øt month 36 ‚Ä¢ Slaves, whom they had redeemed, and among≈øt others ≈øeverall Moncks of the Orders of St. Dominick, St. Francis and St. Au≈øtin. And becau≈øe the money they carried for that purpo≈øe, was not found ≈øufficient for redeeming ≈øo great a number; Father Anthonio de Rigo remained as an O≈øtage, for the performance of the fourth Vow of that Order. The preparations again≈øt Portugal are continued every where, but the ≈øea≈øon being very much ≈øpent already, many are of opinion that they will not be made u≈øe of this yeare.

div.head: Rome 12 June 1660.
div.p: Within the≈øe few daies, Mon≈øieur Boncompagno, Arch-B ‚Ä¢ ≈øhop of Bononia, arived here, and having repaired to ≈øalute the Pope, he declared him his Magior-Dome. The 5 in≈øtant Cardinal Barbarigo, being come to the Palace Quirinal, ‚Ä¢ he received there the Cardinals ‚Ä¢ hat from the Pope's owne hand, after the u≈øuall manner, and having been very ≈øumptuou≈øly fea≈øted by Cardinal Chigi, with Cardinal Mancini, he began his vi≈øits of the Colledge of Cardinalls, by that of Cardinal Barberin, the Sub-Deane of that Colledge.

The 6. Cardinal Vecchiacelli, Bi≈øhop of Rietti, was con≈øecrated in the new Church by Cardinal Ro≈øpiglio≈øi, a≈ø≈øi≈øted therein by Mr. Signi Archbi≈øhop of The≈ø≈øalonica, and Mr. Caraffa Archbi≈øhop of Patra≈ø≈øo. The ≈øame day, the young ≈øon, of whom the Prince≈øs Borghe≈øe was lately delivered, was chri≈øtened in the church of S. Laurence, by Cardinal Chigi, in the Popes behalf, and named Marc Antonio, John Maria, Jo≈øeph, Philip, Thomas, Nicholas, Francis, Dominick, Bernardino, Ga≈øpard and Caetan. The next day the Propo≈øitions were made for the Bi≈øhopricks, and Cardinal d'E≈øte propounded that of Beziers in France, for the Abbot Bonzi.

The 6. in≈øt ‚Ä¢ nt, Te Deum was ≈øung in our Cathedral church for the peace between Swed ‚Ä¢ land, Poland, and their Allies. The ≈øame day, the Dowager Empre≈øs went from hence for ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ enburgh in S ‚Ä¢ iria, where ≈øhe will expect the Dutche≈øs of M ‚Ä¢ n ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , her mother. Since the confirmation of the news of the defeat of Prince Ragotsky's forces, 6000 men have been commanded to march with all ≈øpeed towards the frontiers of Hungaria, to join with the Imperial army, and order hath been given to the Commander in chief, to reinforce the chiefe≈øt garri≈øons, ≈øo that they may hinder the progre≈øs of the Turki≈øh army, who ≈øeem to have a de≈øign to advance that way. But it is thought they will ≈øoon alter their re≈øolutions, if what we have heard by letters from thence prove true, that Prince Ragotsky having gathered the remainder of his forces, hath ≈øo re≈øolutely fallen on the Turki≈øh army, in a narrow place, that 5 or 6000 of them were ≈ølain there, and that he hath regained mo≈øt of the pri≈øoners taken from him. In the mean while, we are confidently informed, that that Prince not finding him≈øelf able to oppo≈øe the forces that are pre ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing again≈øt him, without a very potent a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, hath off ‚Ä¢ red unto the Emperor to put all the important places of Tran≈øilvania into his hands, and wholly to renounce any engagement with the Turki≈øh Empire.

div.head: Regenspurgh, June 15.
div.p: The S. in≈øtant, the Cardinal of O≈ønabruck our Bi≈øhop had his Synod in this place, where he found about 600 Churchmen of this Dioce≈øe, and ended it as he had begun it, by a general Proce≈ø≈øion.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENTS.
div.p: ‚òûThere is now publi≈øhed that long expected and much-de≈øired work entituled, The ≈øecond part of the Signal Loyalty and devotion of Gods true Saints and pious Chri≈øtians under the Go≈øpel (e≈øpecially in this our I≈øland) towards their Chri≈øtian Kings and Emperours, whether Orthodox or Heteredon, virtuous or vicious, Protestants or Papi≈øts, Protectors or Per≈øecutors, ever ≈øince their Kings and Emperours fir≈øt became Chri≈øtian, till this pre≈øent, &c. By William Prynne E≈øq a Bencher of Lincolus-Inne, and a member of this pre≈øent Parliament, which book is dedicated to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, and ≈øold by Edward Thomas at the Adam and Eve in Little-Prittain, where all the ≈øeveral works of this learned and pious Author are to be ≈øold.

The Grand Scipio, an excellent new Romance, written in French by Mon≈øieur de Vaumoriero, and rendred into Engli≈øh by G. H. Printed for H. Mo≈øely, T. Dring, and H Herringman, and are to be ≈øold at their ≈øhops.

The third and la≈øt volume of the Hi≈øtory of Phylo≈øophy, containing the lives of Pythagoras, Democritus, Epicurus, and the re≈øt of the Halick Phylo≈øophers. Print ‚Ä¢ d for H. Mo≈øel ‚Ä¢ y and T. Dring, and are to be ≈øold at their ≈øhops a ‚Ä¢ the Princes Arms in St. Pauls Church-yard, and at the George in Fleet≈øtreet.

Private forms of Prayer fit for ≈øid times; heretofore printed at Oxford, and u≈øed (occa≈øionally) upon daies of ≈øolemn ‚Ä¢ um ‚Ä¢ liation and fa≈øting, in his late Maje≈øties Roy ‚Ä¢ l Chappel of ble≈ø≈øed and glorious memory; al≈øo a form of prayer for the 30th of January, m ‚Ä¢ rnin ‚Ä¢ and eveni ‚Ä¢ g‚ñ™ likewi≈øe prayers of interce≈ø≈øion for the u≈øe of ≈øuch as mourn in ≈ø ‚Ä¢ cret; together with a co ‚Ä¢ lection of ≈øeveral other prayers. Sold by William Not, at the White hor≈øe in St. Pauls Church yard.

Cromwell's bloody ≈ølaughter-hou≈øe; or his damnable de≈øigns laid and practi≈øed by him and his Negro's, in con ‚Ä¢ riving the murther of his ≈øacred Maje≈øty King Charles the fir≈øt, di≈øcovered by a per≈øon of honor. Sold by Iames Davis at the Grey-hound in St. Pauls Church yard. The price is 12 d.

The death of Charles the fir≈øt lamented with the re≈øtauration of Charles the Second congratulated; delivered „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øpeech at the proclaiming of our gracious King, as his Town of Wellington, May 17. 1660. By William Langley, late of Lich ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eld, Mini≈øter now of Wel ‚Ä¢ ington, his Maje≈øties faithful, loyal ≈øubject. Sold by Richa ‚Ä¢ d Lownd ‚Ä¢ s at the white Lyon in St. Pauls Church yard, and Sym. Gape, ne ‚Ä¢ t to Hercules Pillar in Fleet≈øtreet.

The law of charitable u≈øe; wh ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ in the Statute of 43, Eliz. Chap 4. is ≈øet forth and expl ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ ed; with directions how to ≈øue out and pro≈øecute Commi≈ø≈øions grounded upon that Statute. Al≈øo Pr ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ents Inqui≈øitions, and Decrees, with divers Judgements, and Re≈øolutions upon ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eptions and Appeals again≈øt Decrees, and other proceedings upon the ≈øaid St ‚Ä¢ tute by Iohn Herne. Sold by Timothy Twyford,
‚Ä¢ s his ≈øhop within the ‚Ä¢ aner-Temple-gate.

‚òûA Leather Portmanteau lo≈øt at Sittingburn or Roche≈øter, when his Maje≈øty came thither, wherein was a ≈øuit of Camolet de Holland, with 2 little laces in a ≈øeam, tight pair of white gloves, and a pair of Doc ‚Ä¢ lether; about twenty yards of sky-coloured Ribbon twelve penny broad, and a whole piece of black Ribbon ten penny broad; a cloth lead colour'd cloak, with ≈øtore of linnen, a pair of ≈øhooes, ≈ølippers, a Montero, and other things; all which belong to a Gentleman (a near Servant to his Maje≈øty) who hath been too long impri≈øoned and Seque≈øtred, to be now robbed, when all men hope to enjoy their own. If any can give notice, they may leave word with Mr. Samuel Me ‚Ä¢ ne his Maje≈øties Book-binder at his hou≈øe in Little-Britain, and they ≈øhall be thankfully rewarded.

Captain Edward Ranger Foot-po≈øt of Dover is re≈øtored to his place, having been deprived thereof ever ≈øince the year 1648. for his Loyalty to his late Maje≈øty, and lodgeth at the Star on Fi≈øh ≈øtreet-Hill.

WHereas there is a Pamphlet lately publi≈øhed, with no name to it, wherein among≈øt many accu≈øations of ≈øeveral per≈øons, Tho. Viner, Alderman of London (being Sheriff of London when his Prince was murthered) is ≈øaid to be then pre≈øent: This is to acquaint you, that it is a fal≈øe a≈øper≈øion, he being not there when that horrid execution was done, but did declare his dete≈øtation of ≈øo foul and vile an act.

And whereas the Pamphleteer further ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid Alderman Viner got well by ordering the ma≈ø≈øy heaps of plate for the Mint, that is al≈øo fal≈øe, he never having the ordering of any of the Publick ma≈ø≈øy heaps of plate for the Mint, nor did he at any time finger one penny of the Publicks money.
Sir Iohn VVitterong, who had disbur≈øed ≈øeveral great ≈øums of money upon many of his Maie≈øties pictures, to pre≈øerve them from wor≈øe hands, did lately pre≈øent them all to his Maie≈øty gratis.

Mr. Combes lately re≈øtored to his Maie≈øty Land belonging to the Crowne, which he had purcha≈øed at a con≈øiderable value at Hem≈øted in Hertford≈øhire. The like was done by the Town at the ≈øame time that had purcha≈øed the other part. His Maie≈øty was plea≈øed to make Mr. Combes Steward thereof.

There is a particular Li≈øt given unto his Maie≈øty of the names of all ≈øuch as have bought his Maie≈øties Lands, and what they bought, whereby it may fairly be expected that they will be as ju≈øt to his Maie≈øty as tho≈øe hone≈øt Gent. of Hertford≈øhire have been.

div.head: Hamburgh, June 17.
div.p: The Swede and Pole make them≈øelves ready to fall on the Mu≈øcovite, who is much di≈øtre≈ø≈øed by the incur≈øion of the Tartar, who falling into Ru≈ø≈øia, gave the Mu≈øcovite a great overthrow, ≈øack'd and harras'd the Country, and carried away many thou≈øand ≈ølaves. On the other ≈øide the Co≈ø≈øacks are faln in, de≈øtroying all they meet with. The Mu≈øcovites that are hemm'd in at Lochwith, it's thought cannot get off without great lo≈øs, though the Mu≈øcovite dreins all his Garri≈øons to make a body to relieve their Army there. The white Ru≈ø≈øians have made a confederacy to joyn with the Pole again≈øt their Lord and Emperour of Ru≈ø≈øia, as ≈øoon as the Pole ≈øhall march into the Field with a con≈øiderable Army. The Poli≈øh General Carnetzky hath defeated the Mu≈øcovy General Cowingzky, and cut him off 7000 men, who is retreated with the re≈øt toward the Wilda at Lachowitz. There is a di≈øcour≈øe here, that the Swede having yet his Fleet that was kept in by Vice-Admiral de Ruyter at liberty, will joyn with others at Land≈øcrown and Gottenburgh to infe≈øt Arch-Angelo and de≈øtroy the Mu≈øcovite there. The Poles have taken Buckowa, which co≈øt the Mu≈øcovites ≈øo many years ≈øiege, ≈øo that Mu≈øcovy is now reduced to a very ≈øad condition. They thir≈øt after peace, which if not granted them they threaten to cut their Governour Na≈ø≈øorkin in pieces, and extirpate his whole Generation.

The 24 in≈øtant, the Queen made her devotions in the Covent of the Carmelites, Nuns of this place, and the next day their Maje≈øties did the like in the Church of Saint Andrew. The 25, all the Corporations of this place had their audience, being conducted thereto by M. de Saintot, Ma≈øter of the Ceremonies, and at night there was a Spani≈øh Comedy at Court, where the Count de Fuen≈øaldagna and all the other Grandees were pre≈øent. The 26, the Town-hou≈øe gave to their Maje≈øties the diverti≈øement of a
great fire-work erected before their Maje≈øties lodgings. The 27, their Maje≈øties went aboard the great Boat pre≈øented to them by our Jurates at Cadillac, and departed, our Cannon playing all that while, with ≈øeveral volleys of the Kings Musketeers, who went before in two great boats, and were followed in a third boat by his Maje≈øties Trumpeters. The boat wherein were their Maje≈øties was drawn by three barks, in each of which were twelve men rowing in blew coats, laced with ≈øilver lace, and the re≈øt of the Court followed in ≈øeveral other Boats, which made a little, but very plea≈øing Fleet.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p:
On Wedne≈øday the fourth of July, the Mayor, Recorder, Aldermen, and capital Burge≈ø≈øes of the corporation of Donca≈øter, in the County of York, having the honor to be introduced to his Maje≈øty by the Earl of Dunfreeze, Lord Ca≈øtleton, and Sir John Dawney, for a demon≈øtration of their loyalty, duty and affection to his Maje≈øty, humbly pre≈øented by the hands of Thomas Bradford their Mayor, a congratulatory Addre≈øs, wherein they returned all po≈ø≈øible thanks to Almighty God, who had been graciou≈øly plea≈øed to re≈øtore his Maje≈øty to his people, and his people to his Maje≈øties Government, ingaging them≈øelves to defend his Maje≈øties ≈øacred per≈øon and Government again≈øt all oppo≈øers, and therewith the Mayor tendered a ≈øurrender of a Fee-farm rent of 74 l. 13 s. 11 d. ob‚ñ™ per annum, an ancient Flower of the Crown, which being in the≈øe times expo≈øed to ≈øale, they had redeemed out of other hands, and now joyfully re≈øtored them to his Maje≈øty, both which his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed very graciou≈øly to accept of, and returned them thanks, with many particular expre≈ø≈øions of affection and favour to that Town. The ≈øame day Doctor
‚Ä¢ yam, a per≈øon of great learning and integrity, who attended his ≈øacred Maje≈øty in his troubles, as long as his age did enable him to travel, was this day ≈øworn Chaplain Extraordinary to his Maje≈øty.

On Thur≈øday his Sacred Maje≈øty, and both Hou≈øes of Parliament, were entertained by the City of London at Guild-hall; the un≈øea≈øonable weather took off much of the ≈øolemnity which was intended to be performed, ≈øo that his Maje≈øty went into London attended onely by his own hou≈øhold guards, which proceeded in this order, A ‚Ä¢ jutant General Miller rode before at ≈øome little di≈øtance to make way, after whom went Sir William Throckmorton, now Knight Mar≈øhal, his footmen and ≈øervants waiting on either ≈øide of him, before ≈øix Trumpets, then a Kettle-Drum, another Cla≈øs of ≈øeven Trumpets, ≈øix Maces, the Heralds in rich coats, the pages and footmen, and next his Maje≈øties Coach with ≈øix hor≈øes, guarded on both ≈øides with his Maje≈øties Royal Band of Pen≈øioners (walking on foot with their pi≈øtols in their hand, under the Command of the mo≈øt noble and valient E. of Cleaveland their Captain) the Equires and ≈øeveral of his Maje≈øties ≈øervants, next them came the Yeomen of the Guard, then the Lord Chancellor in his Coach, the Duke of Buckingham in his, and ≈øo all the Nobility in their order. The Speaker of the Hou≈øe of Commons in his Coach and ≈øix hor≈øes, attended by a troop of hor≈øe that were upon their guard that day, and after him the Hou≈øe of Commons in Coaches. In London ≈øeveral of the pent-hou≈øes and windows were adorned with Tape≈øtry, a lane made by the Liveries of the ≈øeveral Companies, and many Pageants in the ≈øtreets. In St. Pauls Church-yard, the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and ≈øeveral others of the City richly accoutred met his Maje≈øty, and from thence conducted him to Guild-hall. The Gentlemen of the Artillery led by the mo≈øt valient and learned John Lord Lucas, at Cheap≈øide opened to the right and left, and guarded both ≈øides of the way whil≈øt his Maje≈øty pa≈ø≈øed through. Being come to Guild-hall, Carpets were ≈øpread from the Hall down to the Council-Chamber for his Maje≈øty to tread on. Before dinner Sir William Wild the Recorder made a
Speech to his Maje≈øty, declaring the great honor that his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to be≈øtow on them in deigning formerly to ≈øend to them his mo≈øt gracious Letter and Declaration, and now to adde to that kindne≈øs, by affording them his Royal pre≈øence, &c. At the upper end of the great Hall, the Ho≈øting towards the We≈øt was rai≈øed three a≈øcents, where was placed a Chair of State, and a rich Canopy, where his Maje≈øty and his two Royal Brothers dined, where his Maje≈øties ≈øervants, and ≈øeveral Aldermen and Common-Council-men attended.

The Hou≈øe of Peers, and Hou≈øe of Commons dined at other tables in the great Hall, attended likewi≈øe by Aldermen and Common-Council-men; at the ≈øound of the loud mu≈øick the whole ≈øervice was ≈øet on the Table, and during the whole dinner time they were entertained with variety of mu≈øick, both in≈øtrumental and vocal.
After dinner was a very co≈øtly banquet, and then an interlude, where a Ru≈øtick was repre≈øented, to the content of his Maje≈øty, and the re≈øt of the ≈øpectators.

After this his Maje≈øty retired him into a with-drawing room, where he was plea≈øed to confer the honour of Knighthood on Alderman Reynold≈øon, Mr. Cleyton, the Chamberlain of London, and Colonel Player his ≈øon.

On Friday July 6. The Mayor and Citizens of the ancient City of Lincoln, having drawn up an humble Addre≈øs to his Maje≈øty, together with a re≈øignation of their Fee-farm rent of 81 l. per annum under their Common Seal, did ≈øend the ≈øame by Robert Mar≈øhal E≈øq and VVilliam South Gent. unto Sir Tho. Meres and Iohn Mon≈øon E≈øq who now ≈øerve in Parliament for the ≈øaid City, which was this day delivered.

After a Speech fir≈øt made by Sir Tho. Meres unto his Sacred Maje≈øty, in behalf of the City of Lincoln, repre≈øenting unto his Maje≈øty how oft and how much that City had ≈øuffered in the late War, and how loyal and faithful the Citizens thereof do continue unto his Maje≈øty, and
that as the want of his Maje≈øties Government was their decay, ≈øo he being peaceably re-e≈øtabli≈øh'd, they hope to repair their le≈ø≈øes under his protection and favour, he delivered his Maje≈øty this Addre≈øs.

div.head: To the Kings Mo≈øt Excellent Majesty.
div.p:
YOur Maje≈øties mo≈øt obedient Subjects, the Mayor, Sheriffs, Citizens and Commonalty of your Maje≈øties antient City of Lincoln, do humbly pro≈øtrate them≈øelves before your Maje≈øty, acknowledging that through the general defection of your Maje≈øties Subjects in this your Kingdome from their Allegiance, occa≈øioned by the prevalency of the late pretended powers, they were therein involved with tbe re≈øt of your Maje≈øties Subjects; and therefore do mo≈øt humbly and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øively apply them≈øelves, and lay hold on your Maje≈øties mo≈øt gracious Pardon, and through and under your Maje≈øties gracious favour and clemency do with all humility, as a body incorporate, pre≈øent to your Maje≈øty their ≈øen≈øe and apprehen≈øion of Gods mercy to your Maje≈øties Subiects (giving God the prai≈øe) that Divine Providence hath not onely pre≈øerved your ≈øacred per≈øon in the mid≈øt of many and eminent dangers, but likewi≈øe hath made re≈øtauration of your Maie≈øty in peace to your Subjects, and of them to their Allegiance to your mo≈øt gracious Maie≈øty, as their undoubted Soveraign; next they pre≈øent their hopes and prayers for pro≈øperity and ble≈ø≈øings from Almighty God upon your ≈øacred Maie≈øty, and your Government over them as their King, and beg your protection of their per≈øons and e≈øtates by the antient and known Laws of your Kingdom, and your Maie≈øties afore≈øaid City of Lincoln, & the incorporate body thereof do with al humble ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to your Maie≈øty acknowledg, that during the prevalency of the late pretended powers over them, and the re≈øt of your
Subjects, to avoid the mi≈øchiefs and pre≈ø≈øures which in all probability might have occured, if the Fee farm due from your ≈øaid City had come into the hands and power of ≈øuch as might have made u≈øe of the purcha≈øe of it, to have inv ‚Ä¢ ded their priviledges and intere≈øts. Your afore≈øaid City upon the account of i ‚Ä¢ vitable nece≈ø≈øity, and ≈øelf-pre≈øervation, were con≈øtrained to borrow the ≈øum of ≈øeven hundred pounds, wherewith to purcha≈øe the afore≈øaid Fee-farm of eighty and one pounds per annum.

Now may it plea≈øe your mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, your afore≈øaid Subjects, the Mayor, Sheriffs, Citizens and Comonalty of the City of Lincoln, do hereby for them≈øelves and their Succe≈ø≈øors. Freely and humbly ≈øurrender and re≈øign unto your mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øty, all the right & intere≈øt which they have or may pretend to the ≈øaid Fee-farm rent, by rea≈øon of the afore≈øaid purcha≈øe: And do al≈øo humbly declare, That your ≈øaid City will yearly render to your Maje≈øty, as your undoubted right and due, from time to time, as it becomes payable; and will further with all readine≈øs freely do or make a ‚Ä¢ y further Declaration or publique Act, as your Maje ‚Ä¢ ties Learned Council ≈øhall devi≈øe, for confirmation of the≈øe pre≈øents, or contents of them.

And in te≈øtimony of the unanimous, full and free con≈øent of the whole body incorporate of your Maje≈øties ≈øaid City, they have cau≈øed to be put to their common Seal, the ≈øix and twentieth day of June, in the twelfth year of your Maje≈øties mo≈øt gracious Reign ov ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, &c.

His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed mo≈øt graciou≈øly to receive the Addre≈øs, with ≈øeveral expre≈ø≈øions of favour: and then Sir Tho. Meres did a ≈øecond time humbly upon his knee be≈øeech his Maje≈øty hereafter to vouch≈øafe his favour to that ancient City; which his Maje≈øty granted accordingly, and as an earne≈øt thereof gave them the honor of his Maje≈øties hand.

div.head: At his Excellencies Quarters at the Cock pit.
div.p:
His Excellency makes it his whole bu≈øine≈øs to ≈øettle the Army as may be mo≈øt to his Maje≈øties Service, and in order thereunto hath removed ≈øeveral Officers, and put others in their places. He hath lately removed Capt. P ‚Ä¢ a≈øe
‚Ä¢ nd Capt. Charlit ‚Ä¢ n of Col. Al≈øop's Regiment belonging to the Gari≈øon of Dunkirke, and put Capt, Pope and Capt‚ñ™ Richard Powel in their places.
There is a very confident report that M. Scos, one that ≈øate in the pretended High Court of Ju≈øtice, for tryal of his late Maje≈øty of everble≈ø≈øed memory, is now Pri≈øoner at Dunkirke.
London, Printed by John Macock, and Tho. Newcombe, 1660.
